title: Mechanical Properties of Materials: Tensile Testing, Hardness, and Impact Behavior
subject: Materials Science and Engineering

prerequisite_knowledge: Basic physics of stress and strain

outline: Ductility quantification through tensile testing using % elongation and % reduction in area (Ch.6.4)
Temperature effects on mechanical properties including yield strength, UTS, and ductility (Ch.6.4)
True stress and true strain concepts versus engineering stress/strain (Ch.6.5)
Brittle material failure characteristics and fracture strength (Ch.6.6)
Hardness testing methods: Brinell and Rockwell tests (Ch.6.7)
Strain rate effects and impact behavior in materials (Ch.6.9)
Material selection based on engineering properties and database limitations (Ch.6)

key_terms.definition: Ability of a material to be permanently deformed without breaking when a force is applied. Copper used for wire exhibits high ductility (Ch.6.4)
Quantitative measure of ductility calculated as: % elongation = (l_f - l_0)/l_0 × 100, where l_f is final length after fracture and l_0 is original gauge length (Ch.6.4)
Quantitative measure of ductility calculated as: % reduction in area = (A_0 - A_f)/A_0 × 100, where A_f is final cross-sectional area after fracture and A_0 is original area (Ch.6.4)
Instantaneous stress defined as σ_T = F/A, where A is the actual cross-sectional area at a particular time during deformation, providing more accurate representation than engineering stress (Ch.6.5)
Instantaneous strain defined as ε_T = ∫dl/l = ln(l/l_0) = ln(A_0/A), representing the continuous summing of incremental strains during deformation (Ch.6.5)

Materials that fail at maximum load without necking, where fracture strength equals tensile strength. Very brittle materials like glasses and ceramics have fracture strength = tensile strength = yield strength (Ch.6.6)

Hardness value calculated from BHN = 2F/[πD(D - √(D² - D_i²))], where F is applied load (kg), D is indenter diameter (mm), and D_i is impression diameter. For steel only: UTS (psi) = BHN × 500 (Ch.6.7)

Energy required to fracture a specimen, measured through Charpy or Izod tests. Represents a material's ability to withstand an impact blow, with ductile materials showing higher impact toughness (Ch.6.9)

Specific temperature below which materials transition from ductile to brittle behavior. Determined using Charpy and Izod impact tests. Typically requires DBTT < operating temperature for load-bearing structures (Ch.6.10)
Evaluation of how notches (from machining, fabrication, or design) reduce material toughness. Measured by comparing absorbed energies from impact tests of notched versus unnotched specimens (Ch.6.10)
Rate of deformation application. Tensile testing uses 0.001 s⁻¹ while impact testing uses 1000 s⁻¹. Higher strain rates make materials more brittle due to insufficient time for slip to occur (Ch.6.9)
Process where increased temperature assists formation of ideal crystal structure, decreasing dislocation density and causing grain growth, which reduces yield strength at higher temperatures (Ch.6.4)

concepts.heading: Ductility Measurement and Temperature Effects
bullets: Ductility is quantified through tensile testing by measuring % elongation and % reduction in area (Ch.6.4)

Measurement procedure: (1) Measure original gauge length or cross-sectional area, (2) Measure length or area after specimen breaks (excluding elastic deformation that disappears upon fracture) (Ch.6.4)
Higher temperature effects: most properties decrease (yield strength, UTS, elastic modulus E) while ductility increases (Ch.6.4)

Yield strength decreases at higher temperatures due to: decreased dislocation density (energy assists ideal crystal formation), increased grain size via recrystallization, and potential decrease in strengthening from ultra-fine precipitates as they grow in size (Ch.6.4)
examples: Copper used for wire exhibits high ductility, enabling drawing into thin wires without breaking (Ch.6.4)
The T-2 tanker S.S. Schenectady fractured in 1941 due to brittle fracture of steel at low temperatures, leading to development of the Charpy Impact test (Ch.6.10)
connections: Dislocation motion control (via strain hardening, grain strengthening, solid-solution strengthening) directly affects yield strength and is temperature-dependent (Ch.6.4)
Recrystallization processes link thermal effects to microstructural changes and mechanical property variations (Ch.6.4)

concepts.heading: True Stress and Strain Versus Engineering Measures
bullets: Engineering stress uses original cross-sectional area A_0: S = F/A_0, while engineering strain uses original length: e = Δl/l_0 (Ch.6.5)
True stress uses instantaneous area: σ_T = F/A, and true strain integrates incremental strains: ε_T = ∫dl/l = ln(l/l_0) = ln(A_0/A) (Ch.6.5)
Conversion formulas: σ_T = σ_e(1 + e_e) and ε_T = ln(1 + e_e), though not valid beyond onset of necking (Ch.6.5)
True stress-strain curve differs from engineering curve: same until yield point, no maximum in true stress-strain curve, typically truncated at UTS point (Ch.6.5)
examples: The derivation of true strain conversion is shown on page 197 of the textbook (Ch.6.5)
connections: True stress-strain concepts are essential for accurate modeling of plastic deformation where dimensions change significantly (Ch.6.5)
Necking behavior in ductile materials creates the divergence between engineering and true stress-strain curves (Ch.6.6)

concepts.heading: Hardness Testing Methods and Interpretation
bullets: Hardness test measures resistance to penetration of surface by hard indenter, representing resistance to scratching, indentation, wear, and abrasion (Ch.6.7)
Brinell Hardness Test: Hard steel sphere forced into material surface, impression diameter measured via microscope. Formula: BHN = 2F/[πD(D - √(D² - D_i²))] (Ch.6.7)
For steel only, empirical relationship exists: UTS (psi) = BHN × 500 (Ch.6.7)
Rockwell Hardness Test: Indenter forced into surface, depth measured under load converted to dimensionless HR number. Measures both elastic and plastic deformation (Ch.6.7)

Rockwell uses different indenters (small steel ball for soft materials, Brale diamond cone for hard materials) and loads (60-150 kg) corresponding to scales A, B, C, D, etc. Harder material yields larger hardness number (e.g., HRC 55) (Ch.6.7)
examples: Students perform Rockwell hardness tests on brass blocks in laboratory settings (Ch.6.7)
Brinell method only measures plastic deformation in the typically ~10 mm affected zone (Ch.6.7)
connections: Hardness values often correlate with tensile strength, providing a quick estimation of material properties (Ch.6.7)
Different Rockwell scales allow hardness measurement across wide range of materials from soft polymers to hard ceramics (Ch.6.7)

concepts.heading: Impact Behavior and Strain Rate Effects
bullets: Materials become more brittle under rapid impacts due to high strain rates (1000 s⁻¹ for impact vs 0.001 s⁻¹ for tensile testing). Insufficient time for slip to occur (Ch.6.9)
Impact tests (Charpy and Izod) measure impact toughness: energy required to fracture specimen. Most work occurs through plastic deformation, so ductile materials show higher impact toughness (Ch.6.9)
Impact energy calculation: Difference in potential energy = pendulum mass × g × (h_0 - h_f), representing energy absorbed by specimen during failure (Ch.6.9)
Impact toughness decreases at lower temperatures because slip becomes more difficult, making materials more brittle (Ch.6.9)
Notched specimens in impact tests measure fracture toughness: ability of flawed material to withstand applied loads. Notches reduce toughness in notch-sensitive materials (Ch.6.10)
examples: Silly putty demonstrates strain rate sensitivity: behaves ductilely when pulled slowly but shatters when impacted rapidly (Ch.6.9)

Columbia Space Shuttle disaster: Foam insulation struck wing at high velocity, creating 10-inch hole in thermal tiles. On re-entry, superheated air penetrated and melted aluminum structure, causing catastrophic failure (Ch.6.9)

NASA's 'Crater' program incorrectly assessed damage because it was validated with test samples 400× smaller than actual foam piece that struck wing. Subsequent test with 1.67 lb foam created 16×17 inch hole in tile (Ch.6.9)
connections: Ductile-to-brittle transition temperature is critical for load-bearing structures subject to impacts and notches, especially at low temperatures (Ch.6.10)
Fracture toughness concepts link impact testing to real-world structural integrity assessment (Ch.6.9)

concepts.heading: Ductile-to-Brittle Transition and Material Selection
bullets: Many materials transition from ductile to brittle behavior below a specific temperature, determined using Charpy and Izod impact tests (Ch.6.10)
Ductile-to-brittle transition temperature (DBTT) is defined as temperature where material exhibits 50% of energy between brittle and ductile regions (Ch.6.10)
Load-bearing structures require DBTT below operating temperature to prevent brittle fracture when notches or cracks are present (Ch.6.10)
Not all materials exhibit ductile-to-brittle transition; FCC metals typically maintain ductility at low temperatures while BCC metals show transition (Ch.6.10)

Material selection requires defining required properties: stiffness, strength, ductility, toughness, loading type (constant vs cyclic), impact loading, weight, corrosion resistance, and temperature exposure (Ch.6)
examples: Figure 6.22 shows Izod impact test results for tough nylon thermoplastic polymer, demonstrating impact toughness as function of temperature with defined transition region (Ch.6.10)
The S.S. Schenectady tanker failure in 1941 led to realization that steels can become glass-like and fail by fast/brittle fracture at low temperatures (Ch.6.10)
connections: Microstructure significantly affects mechanical properties even for materials with same nominal composition, requiring careful interpretation of property databases (Ch.6)
Processing methods like welding, riveting, and cutting can introduce defects and alter microstructure, substantially changing mechanical properties from handbook values (Ch.6)

formulas.name: Percent Elongation
formulas.description: Quantifies ductility by measuring permanent deformation after fracture. l_f is final length after specimen breaks (excluding elastic deformation), l_0 is original gauge length (Ch.6.4)
formulas.example: For a specimen with original length 50 mm that fractures at 65 mm, % elongation = (65-50)/50 × 100 = 30%

formulas.name: Percent Reduction in Area
formulas.description: Alternative ductility measure using cross-sectional area change. A_f is final area after fracture, A_0 is original cross-sectional area (Ch.6.4)

variables.meaning: Final cross-sectional area after specimen breaks (mm²)

formulas.example: For original area 10 mm² reducing to 7 mm² at fracture, % reduction = (10-7)/10 × 100 = 30%

formulas.name: True Stress
formulas.description: Instantaneous stress using actual cross-sectional area during deformation, providing more accurate representation than engineering stress (Ch.6.5)

variables.meaning: Instantaneous cross-sectional area at time of measurement (mm²)

formulas.example: During necking, as area reduces from 10 to 8 mm² under 5000 N load, true stress increases from 500 to 625 MPa

formulas.name: True Strain
formulas.description: Continuous summation of incremental strains during deformation, providing accurate strain measure when dimensions change significantly (Ch.6.5)
formulas.example: For length doubling from 50 to 100 mm, true strain = ln(100/50) = ln(2) ≈ 0.693

formulas.name: Engineering to True Stress Conversion
formulas.description: Converts engineering stress to true stress using engineering strain. Not valid beyond onset of necking (Ch.6.5)
formulas.example: At engineering stress 400 MPa and strain 0.1, true stress = 400 × (1 + 0.1) = 440 MPa

formulas.name: Engineering to True Strain Conversion
formulas.description: Converts engineering strain to true strain using natural logarithm. Not valid beyond onset of necking (Ch.6.5)
formulas.example: For engineering strain of 0.2, true strain = ln(1.2) ≈ 0.182

formulas.name: Brinell Hardness Number
formulas.description: Calculates hardness from impression of hard steel sphere indenter. Measures only plastic deformation in affected zone (Ch.6.7)
formulas.example: For 3000 kg load, 10 mm indenter, 4 mm impression: BHN = 2×3000/[π×10(10-√(100-16))] ≈ 286

formulas.name: Ultimate Tensile Strength from Brinell Hardness
formulas.description: Empirical relationship valid only for steel, converting Brinell hardness number to ultimate tensile strength in psi units (Ch.6.7)
formulas.example: For steel with BHN 200, UTS = 200 × 500 = 100,000 psi ≈ 690 MPa

formulas.name: Impact Energy from Charpy Test
formulas.description: Calculates energy absorbed by specimen during fracture in Charpy impact test, representing impact toughness (Ch.6.9)
formulas.example: For 20 kg pendulum dropping from 1.5 m to 0.8 m: Impact energy = 20 × 9.81 × (1.5 - 0.8) = 137.34 J

practice_questions.question: A tensile specimen with original length 50 mm and final length 68 mm after fracture has what % elongation?
practice_questions.explanation: Using % elongation = (l_f - l_0)/l_0 × 100: (68 - 50)/50 × 100 = 18/50 × 100 = 36%. This quantifies the ductility of the material (Ch.6.4)

practice_questions.question: Why does yield strength typically decrease at higher temperatures?
practice_questions.answer: Due to decreased dislocation density, increased grain size via recrystallization, and growth of strengthening precipitates
practice_questions.explanation: Higher temperatures assist formation of ideal crystal structure, reducing dislocation interference. Recrystallization increases grain size, and ultra-fine strengthening precipitates grow larger, decreasing their effectiveness. These microstructural changes collectively reduce yield strength (Ch.6.4)

practice_questions.question: True stress-strain curve differs from engineering curve in that:
practice_questions.answer: It has no maximum and is typically truncated at UTS point
options: It has no maximum and is typically truncated at UTS point
It is identical beyond yield point
It is only valid for brittle materials
practice_questions.explanation: The true stress-strain curve matches engineering curve until yield point but shows no maximum because it uses instantaneous area. It is typically truncated at UTS point for practical analysis (Ch.6.5)

practice_questions.question: For a steel specimen with BHN 250, what is the approximate UTS in psi?
practice_questions.explanation: Using UTS (psi) = BHN × 500: 250 × 500 = 125,000 psi. This empirical relationship is valid only for steel (Ch.6.7)

practice_questions.question: What is the primary reason materials behave more brittle under impact loading?
practice_questions.answer: High strain rates provide insufficient time for slip to occur
options: High strain rates provide insufficient time for slip to occur
practice_questions.explanation: Impact testing uses strain rates of 1000 s⁻¹ compared to 0.001 s⁻¹ for tensile tests. At these high rates, there is insufficient time for dislocation slip to occur, making materials appear more brittle (Ch.6.9)

practice_questions.question: Calculate true strain for an engineering strain of 0.15
practice_questions.explanation: Using ε_T = ln(1 + e_e): ln(1 + 0.15) = ln(1.15) ≈ 0.1398. This conversion is not valid beyond necking onset (Ch.6.5)

practice_questions.question: Why was NASA's 'Crater' program inadequate for assessing Columbia shuttle damage?
practice_questions.answer: It was validated with test samples 400× smaller than actual foam that struck the wing
practice_questions.explanation: The Crater program, developed in the 1970s, had been validated by impact tests but the foam piece that struck the wing was 400× larger than test samples. Subsequent testing with similar 1.67 lb foam created a 16×17 inch hole, demonstrating scale effects in impact behavior (Ch.6.9)

practice_questions.question: What is the significance of ductile-to-brittle transition temperature (DBTT) for load-bearing structures?
practice_questions.answer: DBTT must be below operating temperature to prevent brittle fracture
options: DBTT must be above operating temperature
DBTT must be below operating temperature
DBTT is irrelevant for structural design
practice_questions.explanation: Load-bearing structures subject to impacts and notches require DBTT below operating temperature. If operating temperature falls below DBTT, the material may fracture in a brittle manner when cracks are present (Ch.6.10)

practice_questions.question: A Brinell test uses 3000 kg load, 10 mm indenter, and produces 3.5 mm impression. Calculate BHN.
Which factor does NOT contribute to yield strength decrease at high temperature?
practice_questions.explanation: Increased dislocation density would strengthen material, not weaken it. At high temperatures, dislocation density decreases due to recrystallization forming ideal crystal structure. Grain growth and precipitate coarsening also reduce strength (Ch.6.4)

practice_questions.question: Why do Rockwell hardness tests measure both elastic and plastic deformation?
practice_questions.answer: Because depth measurement under load includes both instantaneous plastic indentation and elastic recovery
practice_questions.explanation: Rockwell test measures depth of impression under load, which includes both permanent plastic deformation and elastic deformation that recovers partially upon load removal. This differs from Brinell which only measures plastic deformation (Ch.6.7)

practice_questions.question: What is notch sensitivity and why is it important?
practice_questions.answer: Notch sensitivity evaluates how flaws reduce material toughness, measured by comparing notched vs unnotched impact test energies
practice_questions.explanation: Notches from machining, fabrication, design, or abrasion reduce material toughness. Notch sensitivity is evaluated by comparing absorbed energies from impact tests of notched versus unnotched specimens. Lower absorbed energy indicates higher notch sensitivity (Ch.6.10)

practice_questions.question: True or False: True stress-strain conversion formulas are valid beyond necking
practice_questions.explanation: The conversion formulas σ_T = σ_e(1 + e_e) and ε_T = ln(1 + e_e) are explicitly stated as not valid beyond onset of necking due to non-uniform deformation (Ch.6.5)

practice_questions.question: What is the primary limitation of material property databases?
practice_questions.answer: Properties are determined under ideal lab conditions and may differ in practice; materials with same composition can have different properties depending on microstructure and processing defects
practice_questions.explanation: Databases contain properties measured under ideal conditions that may not reflect real-world service. Materials with identical nominal composition can have significantly different mechanical properties depending on microstructure. Processing methods like welding, riveting, and cutting introduce defects that alter properties. Therefore, databases must be used with awareness of these limitations (Ch.6)

study_tips: Memorize the three mechanisms controlling yield strength: dislocation motion, grain size, and point defects, and how temperature affects each (Ch.6.4)
Practice converting between engineering and true stress/strain using the provided formulas, but remember they are not valid beyond necking (Ch.6.5)
Understand the difference between hardness tests: Brinell measures only plastic deformation while Rockwell measures both elastic and plastic deformation (Ch.6.7)
Create a comparison table of strain rates: tensile testing (0.001 s⁻¹) vs impact testing (1000 s⁻¹) and explain why higher rates cause brittleness (Ch.6.9)
Study the Columbia disaster case study thoroughly: understand the scale-up problem (400× larger foam) and its impact on validation (Ch.6.9)
For DBTT, always remember the design requirement: DBTT must be less than operating temperature for safe operation (Ch.6.10)
When using material property databases, always consider that processing methods (welding, riveting, cutting) can significantly alter properties from handbook values (Ch.6)
Work through sample calculations for all formulas: % elongation, BHN, impact energy, and true stress/strain conversions

common_misconceptions.misconception: True stress is always lower than engineering stress
common_misconceptions.correction: True stress is higher than engineering stress after yield point because it uses decreasing instantaneous area while engineering stress uses constant original area (Ch.6.5)
common_misconceptions.why_common: Students often assume true stress is 'true' and therefore smaller, but fail to recognize that area reduction during deformation causes true stress to increase more rapidly

common_misconceptions.misconception: Hardness tests measure only plastic deformation
common_misconceptions.correction: Rockwell hardness measures both elastic and plastic deformation because depth measurement includes elastic recovery, while only Brinell measures plastic deformation (Ch.6.7)
common_misconceptions.why_common: Most students generalize from Brinell test and don't recognize the fundamental difference in Rockwell measurement principle

common_misconceptions.misconception: Higher temperature always makes materials weaker in all respects
common_misconceptions.correction: While yield strength and UTS decrease with temperature, ductility actually increases, which is beneficial for fracture resistance (Ch.6.4)
common_misconceptions.why_common: Students focus only on strength reduction and overlook the trade-off of increased ductility at higher temperatures

common_misconceptions.misconception: Impact test results can be directly scaled up to full-size structures
common_misconceptions.correction: Columbia disaster demonstrates that impact tests validated with small samples (400× smaller) failed to predict behavior at full scale due to energy and momentum differences (Ch.6.9)
common_misconceptions.why_common: Linear scaling intuition fails in impact mechanics where kinetic energy and damage mechanisms don't scale proportionally

common_misconceptions.misconception: Material property databases provide exact values for design
common_misconceptions.correction: Handbook values are measured under ideal lab conditions; actual properties vary significantly with microstructure and processing defects introduced during manufacturing (Ch.6)
common_misconceptions.why_common: Students treat tabulated values as absolute constants without understanding the microstructural sensitivity of mechanical properties
